acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 3 from 48 hours EC50=11200microg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 3 (2004) and others.).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (dermal route) value of 700mg/kg representing the lower of the two testing data, 2,322mg/kg and 700mg/kg (CERI Hazard Data 2001-48 (2002)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 296mg/kg (CERI Hazard Data 2001-48 (2002)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Cannot be classified given the insufficiency of data for use in classification along with the absence of existing classification.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since there was rapidly degrading (it was reported that this substance was easy to degrade in the water because  (Saint Lawrence River) (CERI Hazard Data (2002)) and the bio-accumulation was low (log Kow=2.36 (PHYSPROP Database (2005))), it was classified into Not classified.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#2261) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale:
Classified as "flammable" according to HSDB (2005). 
Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#2261) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on in vivo mutagenicity/genotoxicity tests and no strong positive data on mutagenicity tests in vitro, described in CERI Hazard Data 2001-48 (2002), NTP DB (Access on October 2005).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#2261) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to the insufficiency of data for use in a comprehensive evaluation of reproductive toxicity, although the available studies show negative results for teratogenic toxicity.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available (melting point: 49degC (HSDB, 2004), test temperature:140degC)

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence from rabbit eye irritation tests: "eye irritant" (though the severity of effects is unknown) (IUCLID (2002) and RTECS (2003)). Also based on the human evidence of skin and mucosal corrosion (CERI Hazard Data 2001-48 (2002)), suggesting eye corrosion.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on the rabbit and guinea pig skin irritation tests (CERI Hazard Data 2001-48 (2002)): "erythema and ulceration were observed." Also based on the description of human effects: "the substance causes chemical burn and corrosion of the skin and mucosal membranes at the site of contact" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-48 (2002)). Although classified as Category 1A-1C, the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (kidney, liver, spleen)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "degeneration of the liver, kidney and spleen tissues," "loss of hepatic function including detoxification and excretion" (MOE Risk Assessment vol.3 (2004)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (nervous system, heart, kidney)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, muscle twitch, depression of the central nervous system, delirium, loss of consciousness, nausea, vomiting, metabolic acidosis, oliguresis, low blood pressure, heart and kidney damage" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-48 (2002)).
